text: Hi all, anyone know of a quick simple way to view sources for SDK classes of a version different than the one you’re targeting within your app within Android Studio? For example, I’m building an app targeting API 22, but want to step into some API classes while debugging on a API 16 device. I know I can just see the source manually, but hoping to find a way I can continue to debug through it. I can’t temporarily change the app  target to API 16 either because there is a lot of 17+ code that would cause errors if compiled against 16. Thanks for any info all!

after looking at a few stackoverflow posts, i think easiest solution in this case is to do something like <http://stackoverflow.com/a/32252259/5162097> and symlink the source directory of the SDK I’ll be debugging temporarily to the directory that my app is built against….

attachments.title: Android studio shows sources from API of compileSdkVersion when debugging on device with older API
attachments.text: I am debugging with Android Studio (A.S) 1.0.2 with compileSdkVersion 21 set up in build.gradle. When using an emulator with API 21 everything works fine. The problem occurs when debugging on a dev...
attachments.fallback: Android studio shows sources from API of compileSdkVersion when debugging on device with older API

text: Is it normal to have to re-install all your plugins (Fabric, Genymotion, etc) in Android Studio when you update say from 1.3 —> 1.4 or 1.4 —> 1.5? I always remember having to do this and it is getting annoying. During the update I select to use the preferences from previous version.
for right now yes I think you are stuck with that
im not sure that the stable channel releases suffer the same punishment though
canary definitely tells you that up front that its a clean instance
Hmm,  I think I recall stable also having this issue but I’ve run canary for personal stuff and stable for work.
I know for sure that updating to canary wiped all my plugins/preferences out.
